Dear Ms. Klinski:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 For repeat violations, identify why the previous CAP was unsuccessful.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the local office at (866) 685-0006.

ALLEGATION:
On 01/29/22, Youth A and Supervisor 1 got into an argument and began to assault
one another. Supervisor 1 hit youth in the head multiple times.
INVESTIGATION:
This complaint was received 01/31/22 and investigated jointly with the DHHS
Specialist. The complaint noted the following,
Youth A (18) resides at Spectrum Juvenile Justice Services where Supervisor 1
is employed. On January 29, 2022, Youth A and Supervisor 1 got into an
argument. Youth A and Supervisor 1 then began to assault each other.
Supervisor 1 hit Youth A in the head multiple times. Youth A did not have any
marks or bruises and was treated by the facility's nurse. The incident was caught
on video camera.
I interviewed the Director at the facility on 02/01/22, jointly with the DHHS Specialist.
The Director said that it appeared to her that Supervisor 1 hit Youth A during this
altercation. The Director has removed Supervisor 1 from the schedule pending the
3

investigation. Youth A is currently in psychiatric care due to self-harming behaviors.
The video was provided by the Director for review. In summary, the video showed
the following: Video starts about 5:18:57 and Pod 7 can be seen with Supervisor 1,
Youth A and Supervisor 2 in the open common area. Youth A appeared to be
arguing with Supervisor 1. Youth A continued to talk to Supervisor 2 and pointed at
Supervisor 1. Supervisor 2 positioned himself between Youth A and Supervisor 1.
About 5:27:28, Youth A maneuvered around Supervisor 2 and ran up on Supervisor
1, who was near the door that exits the pod. Youth A and Supervisor 1 grabbed one
another, and Supervisor 1 was seen punching at Youth A. It was not clear whether
contact was made. Supervisor 2 separated Youth A from Supervisor 1 and escorted
her to her room.
I interviewed Supervisor 2 at the facility on 02/01/22, jointly with the DHHS
Specialist. Supervisor 2 reported that he came on the pod after receiving a call for
assistance from Supervisor 1. Upon arrival to the pod, Supervisor 2 said that Youth
A was saying to Supervisor 1, “Say to me what you said to Youth B.” Supervisor 2
said that Youth A and Supervisor 1 continued to argue, and Supervisor 2 directed
Supervisor 1 to leave the pod. Supervisor 2 said that he asked Supervisor 1 to leave
the pod “over 10 times” during this incident. Supervisor 2 said that he told Supervisor
1 to open the door and she did not. Supervisor 2 said that Youth A got around him
and went after Supervisor 1. Supervisor 2 said that he separated the two and got
Youth A into a hold and then escorted her into her room after Supervisor 1 opened
Youth A’s bedroom door. Supervisor 2 said Youth B was in her room on the pod but
not involved. Supervisor 2 said that, at the time, he did not see Supervisor 1 hit
Youth A, but stated that it did look like she hit Youth A when he reviewed the video.
Supervisor 2 said that Supervisor 1 did have a hold on Youth A’s hair during the
altercation. Supervisor 2 said that Youth A and Supervisor 1 have had previous
altercations and Youth A assaulted Supervisor 1 about two or three weeks ago.
Youth A was not injured but did see the Nurse the next day. Supervisor 2 said that
Youth A is still out of the facility in psychiatric hospitalization due to self-harming
behavior.
I interviewed Youth B at the facility on 02/01/22, jointly with the DHHS Specialist.
Youth B reported that she was in her room during the altercation between
Supervisor 1 and Youth A. Youth B said that she and Youth A were arguing, but
Youth A’s anger became focused on Supervisor 1. Youth B said that she told
Supervisor 1 not to be afraid of Youth A. Youth A reportedly said she wanted to fight
Supervisor 1 earlier in the day. Supervisor 1 reportedly said that she didn’t come to
work to fight with kids and Youth B said Supervisor 1 was initially backing up from
Youth A. Youth B said Supervisor 1 called for assistance on the radio and
Supervisor 2 came to the pod. Youth B said Supervisor 2 told Supervisor 1 to leave,
to take a break, and to go calm down, but Supervisor 1 stayed. Youth B said she did
not know why Supervisor 1 stayed on the pod. Youth B said that although she was in
her room, she did see Youth A run up on Supervisor 1. Due to the angle from Youth
B’s bedroom and where the altercation occurred, Youth B could not see the actual
physical incident. Supervisor 2 broke up the altercation. After the incident, Youth B
4

said that Supervisor 1 told Youth A that she would have “decked her in her shit if
Supervisor 2 wasn’t there.” Youth B said that after Youth A was secured in her room,
Supervisor 1 continued to staff their pod and continued to argue with Youth A.
Supervisor 2 left the pod once Youth A was secured.
I interviewed Supervisor 1 at the facility, on 02/01/22, jointly with the DHHS
Specialist. Supervisor 1 reported that Youth A and Youth B were arguing, and she
was redirecting them. Youth A then began to focus on Supervisor 1 and said she
was going to take Supervisor 1’s keys. Youth A approached Supervisor 1 and
Supervisor 1 said that she stood up and stepped back. Supervisor 1 said Youth A
was threatening so Supervisor 1 called for assistance. Supervisor 2 arrived on the
pod quickly and was talking to Youth A. Supervisor 1 said that she and Supervisor 2
were trying to deescalate Youth A, and that Youth A calmed down a bit but then
escalated again. Supervisor 1 said she made her way toward the door but stayed on
the pod to ensure Supervisor 2 was ok with the females on the unit. Youth A went by
the staff table with the completed observation sheets, so Supervisor 2 went to
intervene. Supervisor 1 said that Youth A then went around Supervisor 2 and
charged toward her. Supervisor 1 said that Youth A threw a few punches and she
blocked them. Supervisor 1 said that her hands got stuck in Youth A’s hair.
Supervisor 2 restrained Youth A and walked her into her bedroom. Supervisor 1 said
that Supervisor 2 told her to leave the pod when Youth A tried to assault her.
Supervisor 1 said she didn’t think Youth A was going to be assaultive. Supervisor 1
denied hitting Youth A or verbally antagonizing Youth A. Supervisor 1 said that she
didn’t say much to Youth A because she didn’t want to escalate her. Supervisor 1
said Youth B was talking to them through her bedroom door. Supervisor 1 denied
saying Youth A was lucky that Supervisor 1 was there. When asked why she didn’t
leave the pod for about 9 ½ minutes of this incident, Supervisor 1 said that she didn’t
leave because Supervisor 2 is a male, and she didn’t want to leave him alone with
the two female youth. Supervisor 1 also said she didn’t leave because Youth A was
calming and then escalating and cycled between the two. Finally, Supervisor 1 said
she didn’t leave because she didn’t have enough room to get around Youth A to the
door. After Youth A was secured in her room, Supervisor 1 said that she left the pod
briefly and then returned to continue monitoring the two youth. When asked why she
returned to monitor the youth after this altercation, Supervisor 1 said they didn’t have
other staff. I then challenged that another staff or supervisor should have swapped
with her, and she agreed. Supervisor 1 denied any further problems that evening
between she and Youth A but did report that Youth A demonstrated self-harm and
was subsequently taken to the hospital. Supervisor 1 stated that she is a trigger for
Youth A who challenges Supervisor 1 as a peer. Supervisor 1 said that Youth A has
times when her frustrations come out at Supervisor 1. I reiterated that these issues
would have made it all the better for Supervisor 1 to leave the area during this
incident.
It is notable that Youth A was not able to be interviewed during this investigation as
she was hospitalized. The hospital subsequently released Youth A on her own,
5

without contacting the facility or Youth A’s assigned worker. Her whereabouts were
unknown.
Documentation reviewed as part of this investigation:
 Handle with Care training documentation for Supervisor 1. Verbal and
physical components completed within the year.
 Policy review for behavior management completed by Supervisor 1, 12/09/21.
 Suspension pending investigation notice for Supervisor 1, 01/31/22.
 Written statement from Youth A, dated 01/31/22. The statement noted that
Supervisor 1 was on the pod and told Youth A she was ‘going to beat my ass
and that she already has the last time I ran up on her.’ The statement said
nothing would have happened if Supervisor 1 would have left the pod like
asked by Supervisor 2 ‘multiple times.’ Youth A wrote that she ran up on
Supervisor 1 and swung twice. The statement noted that Supervisor 1 ‘hit me
on the top of my head and Supervisor 2 got in between us. Escorted me to
my room.’
 Written statement from Youth B, dated 01/31/22. The statement was
consistent with Youth B’s interview.
 Written statement from Supervisor 1, dated 01/31/22. The statement was
consistent with Supervisor 1’s interview.
 Supervisor 1 had one disciplinary action in her employee file, and it was
related to not properly logging medications on 12/31/21. She was suspended
for three days, 01/20/22-01/22/22.
 Unusual Incident Report, 01/29/22, for Youth A, authored by Supervisor 2.
The report was consistent with Supervisor 2’s interview and the video review.
The report noted that, ‘Youth A charged towards Supervisor 1 who failed to
make use of the physical restraint technique and they began exchanging
punches.’
6

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.158 Discipline.
(2) An institution shall prohibit all cruel and severe
discipline, including any of the following:
(a) Any type of corporal punishment inflicted in any
manner.
ANALYSIS: The facility is in violation of the rule, as Supervisor 1 punched
Youth A during this altercation. While it is not clear if the punch
from Supervisor 1 connected with Youth A, Youth A’s written
statement indicated it did.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2022C0108014 - intake 02/17/22; CAP pending
ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
Supervisor 1 did not demonstrate the ability to fulfill the duties of her job.
INVESTIGATION:
During the course of this investigation, it was observed that Supervisor 1 punched
Youth A instead of using her physical management training. Supervisor 1 remained
on the pod while Youth A escalated and did not leave when directed to do so by
Supervisor 2 numerous times.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4112 Criminal history check, subject to requirements; staff
qualifications.
(4) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the
following:
(a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
ANALYSIS: Supervisor 1 did not demonstrate the ability to perform her job
duties, as evidenced by her punching Youth A and by refusing
to leave the pod when directed to do so by Supervisor 2.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
7

ALLEGATION:
On January 15, 2022, Supervisor 3 picked Youth A up and threw her in her room. As
a result, Youth A hit her head on the doorway. In addition, Youth A has a bruise on
her arm and red abrasion her back from Supervisor 3 grabbing ahold of her.
INVESTIGATION:
This complaint was received on 01/31/22 from DCWL Intake. The complaint was
transferred for investigation by DCWL. The following was reported,
Youth A (18) resides at Spectrum Juvenile Justice Services where Supervisor 3
is employed as a supervisor. On January 15, 2022, Supervisor 3 picked Youth A
up and threw her in her room. As a result, Youth A hit her head on the doorway.
In addition, Youth A has a bruise on her arm and red abrasion her back from
Supervisor 3 grabbing ahold of her shirt or bra, but there is no open skin. Youth A
has an article of clothing, which is possibly her bra with blood on it following the
incident.
DCWL Intake reported that DHHS and DCWL never received notice of this intake,
but it was found when Intake was searching through history for the victim on the
previous complaint. The complaint was then assigned for investigation.
I interviewed the Nurse at the facility on 02/01/22. The Nurse said that Youth A
reported that Supervisor 3 put his hands on her and threw her into a door. The
Nurse said that this incident reportedly occurred the weekend prior to the complaint
being filed. The allegations were reviewed with the Nurse who said that Youth A had
a bruise on her armpit area, but Youth A did not know where it came from. The
Nurse filed the report after meeting with Youth A and hearing the allegations.
I interviewed Supervisor 3 at the facility on 02/01/22. Supervisor 3 said that he was
called to the pod and when he arrived, Staff 1 and Youth A were arguing, and Youth
A was being aggressive toward Staff 1. Supervisor 3 stepped between them, and
Supervisor 4 arrived. At this time, Youth A assaulted Supervisor 4 so she was put in
a two-man escort and taken to her room. Supervisor 3 said that Youth A did not hit
the door, wall, or door frame as she entered the room. Supervisor 3 said this was a
“good two-person escort” and was not excessive. Supervisor 3 denied picking Youth
A up off her feet.
I interviewed Supervisor 4 at the facility on 02/01/22. Supervisor 4 reported that he
responded to a call for assistance and when he arrived to the pod, Youth A was
threatening Staff 1. Supervisor 4 said Youth A was calling Staff 1 “Jennifer” who is a
name from Youth A’s past, but not Staff 1’s name. Supervisor 4 said he stepped
between Youth A and Staff 1. Youth A became assaultive requiring Supervisor 3 and
Supervisor 4 to put Youth A in a two-person escort and then they took her to her
room and let her go. Supervisor 4 said that he did not see Youth A hit her head on
anything during the transport. Supervisor 4 said that when Supervisor 3 debriefed
8

with Youth A, Youth A said she was bleeding but there was no blood anywhere.
Supervisor 4 said that Youth A saw the Nurse the following day because the incident
occurred later at night. Supervisor 4 said he came in the following day and talked
with Youth A, who said she didn’t remember any of the incident.
I interviewed Staff 1 at the facility on 02/01/22. Staff 1 reported that during this
incident Youth A thought Staff 1 was someone else from Youth A’s past and kept
calling her “Jennifer” although that is not Staff 1’s name. Youth A became
aggressive, and Staff 1 continued to back up and stay separated from Youth A.
Supervisors 3 and 4 came to the pod and put Youth A in a two-person escort and
took her to her room at the point Youth A became assaultive. Staff 1 denied seeing
Youth A lifted off the floor and denied seeing Youth A hit her head on anything. After
the incident Staff 1 said Youth A had a scratch on her chest, but noted it was self-
inflicted. Staff 1 also noted that Youth A said her head hurt but didn’t say why or
make a report that something happened to her.
I reviewed video of this incident with the Director on 02/01/22. The video shows
Supervisors 3 and 4 put Youth A in a two-man escort hold and begin walking her to
her room. Youth A pulls up her legs and Supervisors 3 and 4 proceed to carry her for
about 2-3 seconds. Once at the doorway to Youth A’s bedroom, it appears the
supervisors put her in the room on the floor. The view is obstructed, and it cannot be
seen if Youth A hit her head.
Documentation reviewed as part of this investigation:
 Unusual Incident Report, for Youth A, dated 01/16/22, authored by Facility
Manager. The report notes that Supervisors 3 and 4 ‘immediately placed
Youth A in the two-man escort technique for 10 seconds then placed her in
her room for regular sleeping hours.’
 Progress Note for Youth A, dated 01/18/22, authored by the Nurse. Noted
Youth A was examined and reported bruising on her arm and a scratch on her
back from a restraint over the weekend involving Supervisor 3. The injuries
were documented, and the Nurse made a report to DHHS. A photo of
petechiae bruising on one upper, inner arm, near the armpit was provided. A
photo of a vertical scratch on the lower/middle back, along the spine was
provided. The scratch was reported to be about 3.5 inches.
9

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4159 Resident restraint.
(2) Resident restraint shall be performed in a manner that is
safe, appropriate, and proportionate to the severity of the
minor child’s behavior, chronological and developmental
age, size, gender, physical condition, medical condition,
psychiatric condition, and personal history, including any
history of trauma, and done in a manner consistent with the
resident’s treatment plan.
ANALYSIS: The facility is noncompliant with the rule as evidenced by the
two supervisors continuing to take Youth A to her room, after
she lifted her legs up off the floor. The supervisors then
proceeded to carry Youth A by her arms. This is not a safe, nor
appropriate manner in which to manage youth. Once the youth
stopped willingly walking to her room and pulled her feet up, the
escort became a restraint and the staff should have either
lowered her to the floor and held her in place, or disengaged, as
carrying a youth is not permitted in the facility restraint model.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2022C0108014 - intake 02/17/22; CAP pending
ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
The incident report did not accurately identify all aspects of the incident.
INVESTIGATION:
During the course of this investigation, it was observed that the Unusual Incident
Report, authored by the Facility Manager and approved by the Director, did not
identify that Youth A was carried to her room by Supervisors 3 and 4. The carrying
was observed on video. Additionally, the report noted, ‘Youth A has been examined
by the Facility Nurse.’ This is not true, as Youth A was put in her bedroom for
‘regular sleeping hours’ as this incident occurred after 9:10pm. Youth A was not
seen by the nurse until 01/18/22 per the Nursing note.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4159 Resident restraint.
(3) The written policy shall include all of the following:
10

(a) Procedures for the review of an incident of restraint
within 48 hours by a level of supervision above the staff
ordering or conducting the restraint to determine if the
requirements of the institution’s procedures were
adhered to in directing and conducting the restraint.
(c) Procedures for recording restraints as an incident
report.
ANALYSIS: The facility is noncompliant with the rule as evidenced by the
incident report not reflecting that Youth A was carried into her
room by Supervisors 3 and 4. Additionally, the Unusual Incident
Report Summary noted that Youth A was examined by the
Facility Nurse, but this exam did not occur until 01/18/22.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2022C0207017 - intake 01/21/22; CAP pending
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on the findings of this investigation, I recommend no change to the current
license status. This recommendation is contingent on the facility submitting an
acceptable corrective action plan for the noted violations.
